author: JeremyTBradshaw
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 and PowerShell 7+ issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6).

-->

## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$Cert = Get-ChildItem cert:\CurrentUser\My\<Thumbprint>
$Cert.PrivateKey
```

## Expected behavior

In Windows PowerShell 5.1, if the certificate is from a CSP provider, for example 'Microsoft Enhanced RSA and AES Cryptographic Provider', there is a property named **CspContainerInfo** with additional sub-properties available within (e.g. **ProviderName**).

## Actual behavior

In PowerShell 7, there is no such CspContainerInfo property on the private key.  When I check out the class on MS Docs, it seems like it's available in all the different .NET versions (CORE, Framework, 5.0 are the ones I checked).  Any idea why this property is not there with PowerShell 7?

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: JeremyTBradshaw
comments.body:
I found the "Provider" property here:

```powershell
$Cert.PrivateKey.Key.Provider
```

I guess this solves my issue.  I'll still ask - is this different on purpose, or is this still a valid issue?  It feels like a breaking change between 5.1 and 7, which I am not sure is a concern for the developers or not.  I can add logic to test either way based on the PSVersionTable I suppose, though that does stink a little.

comments.author: JeremyTBradshaw
comments.body: Last thing I can think to say - while I have PowerShell 7 installed, I can't install PowerShell 6.  I'd like to know if PowerShell 6 has these properties the same way as 7, or as 5.1, so that I can build logic into my module to test for the provider based on the PSVersionTable.  I'll find a box to install it on, but just as a general question, I'm wondering if I should suspect 6 to be like 7, or like 5.1 as a rule of thumb?  Or should I simply never try to accommodate both PSEditions Core/Desktop with the same pieces of code (which I'd like to do).

comments.author: JeremyTBradshaw

title: Fewer properties on certificates than Windows PowerShell 5.1
